title: Flow cytometric characterization of tissue-resident lymphocytes after murine liver and heart transplantation
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Tissue harvest
Timing: 20 min per mouse
For non-arterialized orthotopic liver transplantation and intra-abdominal heterotopic heart transplantation surgical procedures please refer to (Yokota et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]) and (Corry et al., 1973[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]). Here, we describe the harvesting of transplanted and native hearts and livers from mice. Harvesting of tissues is ideally performed under terminal anesthesia to reduce the risk of thrombosis, though may be done immediately after euthanasia. The transplanted heart is located in the abdomen, thus harvesting of the transplant and native hearts require separate procedures. The transplanted liver replaces the native liver, thus the procedure for harvesting either a transplanted or native liver is the same.
Induce anesthesia and place the mouse in a supine position with continuous anesthetic delivery. Secure the limbs with tape to provide access to the abdomen.
Sterilize the abdomen with 70% ethanol.
Open the mouse:
With forceps, lift the skin at the pelvis and make an incision with scissors.
Continue the incision to the sternum, exposing the peritoneal cavity membrane.
Carefully cut open the peritoneum from the pelvis to the sternum.
Further open the abdomen by incising along the flanks.
Move the abdominal organs aside with cotton tip applicators to expose the transplanted organ.
Proceed with step 5 for liver transplant mice, and steps 6 and 7 for heart transplant mice.
Perfuse and collect the transplanted liver (Methods videos S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1], S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2], and S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3]):
Locate and incompletely sever the inferior vena cava (IVC) at the top of the liver (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Perfuse the liver with 10 mL cold saline by inserting a 23 G needle attached to a 10 mL syringe into the IVC. The liver will blanch and appear pale with correct perfusion.
Remove and discard the gallbladder (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]).

Resect the liver, taking care to cut any adhesions to the surrounding tissue (Methods video S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3]), place in DMEM and keep on ice.

Perfuse the mouse and collect the transplanted heart (Methods video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4]):
Perfuse the mouse by injecting 3 mL cold saline into the abdominal aorta using a 30 G needle below the heart graft. The transplanted heart will become pale with correct perfusion.
Cut the aorta and soak up the perfusate with a cotton ball.
Resect the heart graft from the abdomen, place in DMEM and keep on ice.

Collect the native heart (Methods video S5[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc5]):
Cut both lateral sides of the rib cage and the diaphragm.
Clamp the sternum with clamp forceps and invert to expose the chest cavity.
Isolate and resect the heart from the chest cavity, place in DMEM and keep on ice.
Critical: Ensure the entire liver is well perfused to limit collection of blood-borne cells that will contaminate the tissue-resident leukocyte populations of interest.
Note: Other tissues such as blood (prior to euthanasia), spleen, lymph nodes and bone marrow can also be harvested for analysis and should be collected into DMEM and placed on ice prior to processing.

Preparation of single-cell suspension from liver tissue

Timing: 1 h
This step describes the process of mechanical disruption and differential centrifugation of liver tissue to prepare a single-cell suspension of leukocytes for flow cytometry (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]). We have found that compared to enzymatic digestion, mechanical disruption has reduced impact on the expression of markers of interest, but does not allow for isolation of Kupffer cells.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1009-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Illustration of liver leukocyte isolation procedure
Record the weight of liver tissue to be used for flow cytometry if taking a section for histology.
Place the liver into a 70 μm cell strainer atop a 50 mL tube.
Mash the liver through the strainer with the rubber end of a 3 mL syringe plunger, rinsing with FACS buffer (Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 × g with swinging buckets for 3 min at 21°C–23°C then carefully remove and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 1 mL 42% isotonic Percoll and transfer to a 15 mL tube. Wash the original tube with 4 mL 42% isotonic Percoll and combine in the 15 mL tube.
Critical: Ensure Percoll is at 21°C–23°C before use.
Centrifuge at 800 × g for 20 min at 21°C–23°C with no brake to separate hepatocytes (top cellular layer) and leukocytes (pellet).
Critical: Ensure brake is off during centrifugation.
Carefully remove and discard the top cellular layer and Percoll from the pellet (Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Resuspend the pellet in 100 μL of RBC Lysis buffer and transfer to a new 15 mL tube containing 4.8 mL of RBC Lysis buffer (Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Critical: Transfer pellet to new tube to avoid contamination with hepatocytes.
Wash the bottom of the original 15 mL tube with another 100 μL of RBC Lysis buffer, combine in the new 15 mL tube and mix well.

Incubate for 5 min at 21°C–23°C with occasional shaking.
Add 5 mL FACS buffer and centrifuge at 300 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C to re-pellet the leukocytes. At this point the pellet should be pale and free of RBCs.
Resuspend the pellet in 400 μL of FACS buffer and count with 5–10 μL of the cell suspension (Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Pause point: Samples can be kept on ice for 1–2 h until ready to proceed to the next step.
Preparation of single-cell suspension from heart tissue
Timing: 1 h 40 min
This step describes the process of enzymatic digestion and differential centrifugation of heart tissue to prepare a single-cell suspension of leukocytes for flow cytometry (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1009-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Illustration of heart leukocyte enzymatic digestion and differential centrifugation isolation procedure
Record the weight of heart tissue to be used for flow cytometry if taking a section for histology.
Transfer the heart to a 60 mm petri dish and rinse with PBS.
Dissect the heart in half lengthways, rinse again with PBS and transfer to a clean 60 mm petri dish.
Inject 500 μL of the heart digestion cocktail into the heart tissue. Disperse the cocktail evenly throughout the tissue by injecting at multiple points.
Decant the remaining 4.5 mL of the digestion cocktail into the petri dish with the heart.
Incubate for 10 min at 37°C with gentle shaking at 80 rpm.
Remove the heart from the digestion cocktail (e.g., to the petri dish lid) and mince with a scalpel until pieces are approximately 0.5–1 mm3 in size.
Resuspend the minced heart tissue in the digestion cocktail and transfer to a 50 mL tube.
Incubate for 30 min at 37°C with shaking at 150 rpm to prevent the tissue from settling.

Pass through a 70 μm strainer, mashing any remaining clumps gently through with the rubber end of a 3 mL syringe plunger.
Rinse the cell strainer with 10 mL DMEM with 15% HI-NCS.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C to pellet cells then carefully remove and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 1 mL 42% isotonic Percoll, transfer to a new 15 mL tube, wash the tube with a further 4 mL 42% isotonic Percoll and combine in the new tube.
Centrifuge at 800 × g for 20 min at 21°C–23°C with no brake to separate parenchymal cells (top layer) and leukocytes (pellet).
Critical: Ensure brake is off during centrifugation.
Carefully and completely remove and discard the top cellular layer and supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 100 μL RBC lysis buffer and transfer to new 15 mL tube containing 900 μL RBC lysis buffer (Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Rinse the bottom of the tube with a further 100 μL RBC lysis buffer and combine in new tube.
Incubate for 2 min at 21°C–23°C until RBCs are lysed.
Add 5 mL FACS buffer and centrifuge at 300 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C to re-pellet the leukocytes. At this point the pellet should be pale and free of RBCs.
Resuspend the pellet in 100 μL of FACS buffer and count with 5–10 μL of the cell suspension (Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Stimulation for functional analysis
Timing: 4 h 15 min

Here we describe the in vitro stimulation of isolated leukocytes for the analysis of cytokine and cytotoxic granule production by T cells (CD8αβ T, CD4 T, regulatory T (Treg), natural killer T (NKT), CD8αα T, and CD8-CD4- double-negative (DN) T cells) (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]). Stimulation reveals the capacity of these cells to produce these cytokines and granules, while unstimulated controls show the existing activity of the cells. Both stimulated and unstimulated samples should contain the same number of cells per well and simultaneously be subjected to identical incubation times and conditions.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1009-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Illustration of leukocyte stimulation procedure
Transfer 0.1–4 × 106 cells per well to a 96 well U bottom plate.
Pellet the cells by centrifugation at 200 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C and flick the plate firmly over a waste receptacle to discard the supernatant.
In unstimulated wells, resuspend the cells in 200 μL DMEM with 10% HI-NCS. In stimulated wells, resuspend the cells in 200 μL Cell Activation Cocktail diluted 1:500 in DMEM with 10% HI-NCS.
Incubate for 4 h at 37°C with 5% CO2.
Pellet the cells by centrifugation at 200 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C and discard the supernatant.
Continue with the ‘staining for flow cytometry’ step below using a panel such as that detailed in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2].
table:files/protocols_protocol_1009_9.csv
Note: Intracellular antibodies are: IFNγ, granzyme B, IL-10 and FoxP3. All remaining antibodies are for surface staining use. For exact antibodies, see key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
Staining for flow cytometry
Timing: 2 h
This major step details the method of staining isolated leukocytes for identifying and characterizing lymphocyte populations (CD8αβ T, CD4 T, Treg, NKT, CD8αα T, and DN T cells). We have performed staining in 96 well U-bottom plates, however this can also be done in Eppendorf or FACS tubes.

Transfer 0.1–4 × 106 cells per well for staining.
Pellet the cells by centrifugation at 200 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C and discard supernatant.
Note: This protocol uses Zombie UV for assessing the viability of cells prior to surface marker staining; therefore cells must be in a protein-free buffer such as PBS during this step.
Wash the cells by resuspending in 150 μL PBS then pellet the cells by centrifugation at 200 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in 40 μL Zombie UV solution diluted 1:1000 in PBS.
Incubate for 20 min at 21°C–23°C in the dark.
Wash the cells with 150 μL FACS buffer.
Pause point: Samples can be kept on ice for 1–2 h until ready to proceed to the next step.
Pellet the cells by centrifugation at 200 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C and discard supernatant.
Note: CD69 and CD49a markers should be included for analysis of tissue-resident populations as the majority express a CD69+CD49a+ phenotype (Mackay et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]; Prosser et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]). In the liver, CXCR6 is also a useful inclusion as many tissue-resident lymphocytes express this molecule (Prosser et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]).
Resuspend the cells in 40 μL surface antibody cocktail as per Tables 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2] or 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3].
table:files/protocols_protocol_1009_10.csv
Note: Intracellular antibodies are: GATA3, T-bet, RORγt, FoxP3 and Eomes. All remaining antibodies are used for surface staining. For exact antibodies, see key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
Incubate for 20 min at 21°C–23°C in the dark.
Wash the cells with 150 μL FACS buffer then pellet the cells by centrifugation at 200 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend in 100 μL of Fixation/Permeabilization buffer.
Incubate for 10 min at 21°C–23°C in the dark.
Add 100 μL of Permeabilization buffer and mix well.

Pellet cells by centrifugation at 800 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C and discard supernatant.
Note: Centrifugation speed is higher after permeabilization to ensure adequate pelleting of cells.
Wash the cells by adding 150 μL of Permeabilization buffer then pellet the cells by centrifugation at 500 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C and discard supernatant.
Add 20 μL of the intracellular antibody cocktail as per Tables 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2] or 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3] and incubate for 20 min at 21°C–23°C in the dark.
Wash the cells by adding 150 μL of Permeabilization buffer then pellet the cells by centrifugation at 500 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C and discard supernatant.
Wash the cells once more by adding 150 μL of FACS buffer then pellet the cells by centrifugation at 500 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in 100 μL 1× BD Stabilizing Fixative and incubate for 15 min at 21°C–23°C in the dark.
Add 150 μL FACS buffer then pellet the cells by centrifugation at 500 × g for 3 min at 21°C–23°C and discard supernatant.
Resuspend in 150 μL FACS buffer.
Cells are now ready for analysis on a flow cytometer (Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]). Samples may be transferred to appropriate tubes or plates to suit individual cytometer requirements.
Pause point: Cells may be stored at 4°C in the dark for up to 4 days prior to analysis.
Critical: The suggested flow cytometry panels require the following appropriate controls. For detailed information for each of the recommended resources please refer to the key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
Compensation Controls
UltraComp eBeads compensation beads are recommended to achieve reliable and robust positive and negative populations for the fluorochromes listed in each suggested antibody panel.
Flow cytometer setup and quality control

BD Cytometer Setup and Tracking (CST) Beads consist of bright, mid and dim beads dyed with a mixture of fluorochromes. Using CST beads, the BD acquisition software measures changes in median fluorescence intensity and robust CV for each bead intensity in all fluorescence detectors and reports on changes from baseline. It is recommended to run CST each time the cytometer is switched on to confirm consistency of data being acquired.
Ultra Rainbow Calibration Particle (URCP) Kits
Similar to CST beads, URCP allow for rapid routine calibration and long-term performance tracking of flow cytometers. URCP produce standardized multiple peaks in each fluorescence detector, which can be easily tracked for changes in cytometer performance. It is recommended to run URCP at the start of each data acquisition experiment.
Fluorescence Minus One (FMO) Controls
FMO controls are recommended for gating accuracy and confirmation of fluorochrome spread. For each panel, it is recommended to prepare FMO control samples for each non-lineage phenotypic or functional marker.
